00048 /*
00049  * uIP is a small implementation of the IP, UDP and TCP protocols (as
00050  * well as some basic ICMP stuff). The implementation couples the IP,
00051  * UDP, TCP and the application layers very tightly. To keep the size
00052  * of the compiled code down, this code frequently uses the goto
00053  * statement. While it would be possible to break the uip_process()
00054  * function into many smaller functions, this would increase the code
00055  * size because of the overhead of parameter passing and the fact that
00056  * the optimier would not be as efficient.
00057  *
00058  * The principle is that we have a small buffer, called the uip_buf,
00059  * in which the device driver puts an incoming packet. The TCP/IP
00060  * stack parses the headers in the packet, and calls the
00061  * application. If the remote host has sent data to the application,
00062  * this data is present in the uip_buf and the application read the
00063  * data from there. It is up to the application to put this data into
00064  * a byte stream if needed. The application will not be fed with data
00065  * that is out of sequence.
00066  *
00067  * If the application whishes to send data to the peer, it should put
00068  * its data into the uip_buf. The uip_appdata pointer points to the
00069  * first available byte. The TCP/IP stack will calculate the
00070  * checksums, and fill in the necessary header fields and finally send
00071  * the packet back to the peer.
00072  */
00073

00077 #include "net/uip-nd6.h"

00128 /**
00129  * \brief Type of the next header in IPv6 header or extension headers
00130  *
00131  * Can be the next header field in the IPv6 header or in an extension header.
00132  * When doing fragment reassembly, we must change the value of the next header
00133  * field in the header before the fragmentation header, hence we need a pointer
00134  * to this field.
00135  */
00136 u8_t *uip_next_hdr;
00137 /** \brief bitmap we use to record which IPv6 headers we have already seen */
00138 u8_t uip_ext_bitmap = 0;
00139 /**
00140  * \brief length of the extension headers read. updated each time we process
00141  * a header
00142  */
00143 u8_t uip_ext_len = 0;
00144 /** \brief length of the header options read */

00274 #if (!UIP_ARCH_ADD32 && UIP_TCP)
00275 void
00276 uip_add32(u8_t *op32, u16_t op16)
00277 {
00278   uip_acc32[3] = op32[3] + (op16 & 0xff);
00279   uip_acc32[2] = op32[2] + (op16 >> 8);
00280   uip_acc32[1] = op32[1];
00281   uip_acc32[0] = op32[0];
00282   
00283   if(uip_acc32[2] < (op16 >> 8)) {
00284     ++uip_acc32[1];
00285     if(uip_acc32[1] == 0) {
00286       ++uip_acc32[0];
00287     }
00288   }
00289   
00290   
00291   if(uip_acc32[3] < (op16 & 0xff)) {
00292     ++uip_acc32[2];
00293     if(uip_acc32[2] == 0) {
00294       ++uip_acc32[1];
00295       if(uip_acc32[1] == 0) {
00296         ++uip_acc32[0];
00297       }
00298     }
00299   }
00300 }
00301 
00302 #endif /* UIP_ARCH_ADD32 && UIP_TCP */
00303 
00304 #if ! UIP_ARCH_CHKSUM
00305 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00306 static u16_t
00307 chksum(u16_t sum, const u8_t *data, u16_t len)
00308 {
00309   u16_t t;
00310   const u8_t *dataptr;
00311   const u8_t *last_byte;
00312 
00313   dataptr = data;
00314   last_byte = data + len - 1;
00315   
00316   while(dataptr < last_byte) {   /* At least two more bytes */
00317     t = (dataptr[0] << 8) + dataptr[1];
00318     sum += t;
00319     if(sum < t) {
00320       sum++;      /* carry */
00321     }
00322     dataptr += 2;
00323   }
00324   
00325   if(dataptr == last_byte) {
00326     t = (dataptr[0] << 8) + 0;
00327     sum += t;
00328     if(sum < t) {
00329       sum++;      /* carry */
00330     }
00331   }
00332 
00333   /* Return sum in host byte order. */
00334   return sum;
00335 }
00336 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00337 u16_t
00338 uip_chksum(u16_t *data, u16_t len)
00339 {
00340   return uip_htons(chksum(0, (u8_t *)data, len));
00341 }
00342 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00343 #ifndef UIP_ARCH_IPCHKSUM
00344 u16_t
00345 uip_ipchksum(void)
00346 {
00347   u16_t sum;
00348 
00349   sum = chksum(0, &uip_buf[UIP_LLH_LEN], UIP_IPH_LEN);
00350   PRINTF("uip_ipchksum: sum 0x%04x\n", sum);
00351   return (sum == 0) ? 0xffff : uip_htons(sum);
00352 }
00353 #endif
00354 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00355 static u16_t
00356 upper_layer_chksum(u8_t proto)
00357 {
00358 /* gcc 4.4.0 - 4.6.1 (maybe 4.3...) with -Os on 8 bit CPUS incorrectly compiles:
00359  * int bar (int);
00360  * int foo (unsigned char a, unsigned char b) {
00361  *   int len = (a << 8) + b; //len becomes 0xff00&<random>+b
00362  *   return len + bar (len);
00363  * }
00364  * upper_layer_len triggers this bug unless it is declared volatile.
00365  * See https://sourceforge.net/apps/mantisbt/contiki/view.php?id=3
00366  */
00367   volatile u16_t upper_layer_len;
00368   u16_t sum;
00369   
00370   upper_layer_len = (((u16_t)(UIP_IP_BUF->len[0]) << 8) + UIP_IP_BUF->len[1] - uip_ext_len) ;
00371   
00372   /* First sum pseudoheader. */
00373   /* IP protocol and length fields. This addition cannot carry. */
00374   sum = upper_layer_len + proto;
00375   /* Sum IP source and destination addresses. */
00376   sum = chksum(sum, (u8_t *)&UIP_IP_BUF->srcipaddr, 2 * sizeof(uip_ipaddr_t));
00377 
00378   /* Sum TCP header and data. */
00379   sum = chksum(sum, &uip_buf[UIP_IPH_LEN + UIP_LLH_LEN + uip_ext_len],
00380                upper_layer_len);
00381     
00382   return (sum == 0) ? 0xffff : uip_htons(sum);
00383 }
00384 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00385 u16_t
00386 uip_icmp6chksum(void)
00387 {
00388   return upper_layer_chksum(UIP_PROTO_ICMP6);
00389   
00390 }
00391 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00392 #if UIP_TCP
00393 u16_t
00394 uip_tcpchksum(void)
00395 {
00396   return upper_layer_chksum(UIP_PROTO_TCP);
00397 }
00398 #endif /* UIP_TCP */
00399 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00400 #if UIP_UDP && UIP_UDP_CHECKSUMS
00401 u16_t
00402 uip_udpchksum(void)
00403 {
00404   return upper_layer_chksum(UIP_PROTO_UDP);
00405 }
00406 #endif /* UIP_UDP && UIP_UDP_CHECKSUMS */
00407 #endif /* UIP_ARCH_CHKSUM */
00408 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00409 void
00410 uip_init(void)
00411 {
00412    
00413   uip_ds6_init();
00414 
00415 #if UIP_TCP
00416   for(c = 0; c < UIP_LISTENPORTS; ++c) {
00417     uip_listenports[c] = 0;
00418   }
00419   for(c = 0; c < UIP_CONNS; ++c) {
00420     uip_conns[c].tcpstateflags = UIP_CLOSED;
00421   }
00422 #endif /* UIP_TCP */
00423 
00424 #if UIP_ACTIVE_OPEN || UIP_UDP
00425   lastport = 1024;
00426 #endif /* UIP_ACTIVE_OPEN || UIP_UDP */
00427 
00428 #if UIP_UDP
00429   for(c = 0; c < UIP_UDP_CONNS; ++c) {
00430     uip_udp_conns[c].lport = 0;
00431   }
00432 #endif /* UIP_UDP */
00433 }
00434 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00435 #if UIP_TCP && UIP_ACTIVE_OPEN
00436 struct uip_conn *
00437 uip_connect(uip_ipaddr_t *ripaddr, u16_t rport)
00438 {
00439   register struct uip_conn *conn, *cconn;
00440   
00441   /* Find an unused local port. */
00442  again:
00443   ++lastport;
00444 
00445   if(lastport >= 32000) {
00446     lastport = 4096;
00447   }
00448 
00449   /* Check if this port is already in use, and if so try to find
00450      another one. */
00451   for(c = 0; c < UIP_CONNS; ++c) {
00452     conn = &uip_conns[c];
00453     if(conn->tcpstateflags != UIP_CLOSED &&
00454        conn->lport == uip_htons(lastport)) {
00455       goto again;
00456     }
00457   }
00458 
00459   conn = 0;
00460   for(c = 0; c < UIP_CONNS; ++c) {
00461     cconn = &uip_conns[c];
00462     if(cconn->tcpstateflags == UIP_CLOSED) {
00463       conn = cconn;
00464       break;
00465     }
00466     if(cconn->tcpstateflags == UIP_TIME_WAIT) {
00467       if(conn == 0 ||
00468          cconn->timer > conn->timer) {
00469         conn = cconn;
00470       }
00471     }
00472   }
00473 
00474   if(conn == 0) {
00475     return 0;
00476   }
00477   
00478   conn->tcpstateflags = UIP_SYN_SENT;
00479 
00480   conn->snd_nxt[0] = iss[0];
00481   conn->snd_nxt[1] = iss[1];
00482   conn->snd_nxt[2] = iss[2];
00483   conn->snd_nxt[3] = iss[3];
00484 
00485   conn->rcv_nxt[0] = 0;
00486   conn->rcv_nxt[1] = 0;
00487   conn->rcv_nxt[2] = 0;
00488   conn->rcv_nxt[3] = 0;
00489 
00490   conn->initialmss = conn->mss = UIP_TCP_MSS;
00491   
00492   conn->len = 1;   /* TCP length of the SYN is one. */
00493   conn->nrtx = 0;
00494   conn->timer = 1; /* Send the SYN next time around. */
00495   conn->rto = UIP_RTO;
00496   conn->sa = 0;
00497   conn->sv = 16;   /* Initial value of the RTT variance. */
00498   conn->lport = uip_htons(lastport);
00499   conn->rport = rport;
00500   uip_ipaddr_copy(&conn->ripaddr, ripaddr);
00501   
00502   return conn;
00503 }
00504 #endif /* UIP_TCP && UIP_ACTIVE_OPEN */
00505 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00506 #if UIP_UDP
00507 struct uip_udp_conn *
00508 uip_udp_new(const uip_ipaddr_t *ripaddr, u16_t rport)
00509 {
00510   register struct uip_udp_conn *conn;
00511   
00512   /* Find an unused local port. */
00513  again:
00514   ++lastport;
00515 
00516   if(lastport >= 32000) {
00517     lastport = 4096;
00518   }
00519   
00520   for(c = 0; c < UIP_UDP_CONNS; ++c) {
00521     if(uip_udp_conns[c].lport == uip_htons(lastport)) {
00522       goto again;
00523     }
00524   }
00525 
00526   conn = 0;
00527   for(c = 0; c < UIP_UDP_CONNS; ++c) {
00528     if(uip_udp_conns[c].lport == 0) {
00529       conn = &uip_udp_conns[c];
00530       break;
00531     }
00532   }
00533 
00534   if(conn == 0) {
00535     return 0;
00536   }
00537   
00538   conn->lport = UIP_HTONS(lastport);
00539   conn->rport = rport;
00540   if(ripaddr == NULL) {
00541     memset(&conn->ripaddr, 0, sizeof(uip_ipaddr_t));
00542   } else {
00543     uip_ipaddr_copy(&conn->ripaddr, ripaddr);
00544   }
00545   conn->ttl = uip_ds6_if.cur_hop_limit;
00546   
00547   return conn;
00548 }
00549 #endif /* UIP_UDP */
00550 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00551 #if UIP_TCP
00552 void
00553 uip_unlisten(u16_t port)
00554 {
00555   for(c = 0; c < UIP_LISTENPORTS; ++c) {
00556     if(uip_listenports[c] == port) {
00557       uip_listenports[c] = 0;
00558       return;
00559     }
00560   }
00561 }
00562 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00563 void
00564 uip_listen(u16_t port)
00565 {
00566   for(c = 0; c < UIP_LISTENPORTS; ++c) {
00567     if(uip_listenports[c] == 0) {
00568       uip_listenports[c] = port;
00569       return;
00570     }
00571   }
00572 }
00573 #endif
00574 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00575 
00576 #if UIP_CONF_IPV6_REASSEMBLY
00577 #define UIP_REASS_BUFSIZE (UIP_BUFSIZE - UIP_LLH_LEN)
00578 
00579 static u8_t uip_reassbuf[UIP_REASS_BUFSIZE];
00580 
00581 static u8_t uip_reassbitmap[UIP_REASS_BUFSIZE / (8 * 8)];
00582 /*the first byte of an IP fragment is aligned on an 8-byte boundary */
00583 
00584 static const u8_t bitmap_bits[8] = {0xff, 0x7f, 0x3f, 0x1f,
00585                                     0x0f, 0x07, 0x03, 0x01};
00586 static u16_t uip_reasslen;
00587 static u8_t uip_reassflags;
00588 
00589 #define UIP_REASS_FLAG_LASTFRAG 0x01
00590 #define UIP_REASS_FLAG_FIRSTFRAG 0x02
00591 #define UIP_REASS_FLAG_ERROR_MSG 0x04
00592 
00593 
00594 /*
00595  * See RFC 2460 for a description of fragmentation in IPv6
00596  * A typical Ipv6 fragment
00597  *  +------------------+--------+--------------+
00598  *  |  Unfragmentable  |Fragment|    first     |
00599  *  |       Part       | Header |   fragment   |
00600  *  +------------------+--------+--------------+
00601  */
00602 
00603 
00604 struct etimer uip_reass_timer; /* timer for reassembly */
00605 u8_t uip_reass_on; /* equal to 1 if we are currently reassembling a packet */
00606 
00607 static u32_t uip_id; /* For every packet that is to be fragmented, the source
00608                         node generates an Identification value that is present
00609                         in all the fragments */
00610 #define IP_MF   0x0001
00611 
00612 static u16_t
00613 uip_reass(void)
00614 {
00615   u16_t offset=0;
00616   u16_t len;
00617   u16_t i;
00618   
00619   /* If ip_reasstmr is zero, no packet is present in the buffer */
00620   /* We first write the unfragmentable part of IP header into the reassembly
00621      buffer. The reset the other reassembly variables. */
00622   if(uip_reass_on == 0) {
00623     PRINTF("Starting reassembly\n");
00624     memcpy(FBUF, UIP_IP_BUF, uip_ext_len + UIP_IPH_LEN);
00625     /* temporary in case we do not receive the fragment with offset 0 first */
00626     etimer_set(&uip_reass_timer, UIP_REASS_MAXAGE*CLOCK_SECOND);
00627     uip_reass_on = 1;
00628     uip_reassflags = 0;
00629     uip_id = UIP_FRAG_BUF->id;
00630     /* Clear the bitmap. */
00631     memset(uip_reassbitmap, 0, sizeof(uip_reassbitmap));
00632   }
00633   /*
00634    * Check if the incoming fragment matches the one currently present
00635    * in the reasembly buffer. If so, we proceed with copying the fragment
00636    * into the buffer.
00637    */
00638   if(uip_ipaddr_cmp(&FBUF->srcipaddr, &UIP_IP_BUF->srcipaddr) &&
00639      uip_ipaddr_cmp(&FBUF->destipaddr, &UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr) &&
00640      UIP_FRAG_BUF->id == uip_id) {
00641     len = uip_len - uip_ext_len - UIP_IPH_LEN - UIP_FRAGH_LEN;
00642     offset = (uip_ntohs(UIP_FRAG_BUF->offsetresmore) & 0xfff8);
00643     /* in byte, originaly in multiple of 8 bytes*/
00644     PRINTF("len %d\n", len);
00645     PRINTF("offset %d\n", offset);
00646     if(offset == 0){
00647       uip_reassflags |= UIP_REASS_FLAG_FIRSTFRAG;
00648       /*
00649        * The Next Header field of the last header of the Unfragmentable
00650        * Part is obtained from the Next Header field of the first
00651        * fragment's Fragment header.
00652        */
00653       *uip_next_hdr = UIP_FRAG_BUF->next;
00654       memcpy(FBUF, UIP_IP_BUF, uip_ext_len + UIP_IPH_LEN);
00655       PRINTF("src ");
00656       PRINT6ADDR(&FBUF->srcipaddr);
00657       PRINTF("dest ");
00658       PRINT6ADDR(&FBUF->destipaddr);
00659       PRINTF("next %d\n", UIP_IP_BUF->proto);
00660       
00661     }
00662     
00663     /* If the offset or the offset + fragment length overflows the
00664        reassembly buffer, we discard the entire packet. */
00665     if(offset > UIP_REASS_BUFSIZE ||
00666        offset + len > UIP_REASS_BUFSIZE) {
00667       uip_reass_on = 0;
00668       etimer_stop(&uip_reass_timer);
00669       return 0;
00670     }
00671 
00672     /* If this fragment has the More Fragments flag set to zero, it is the
00673        last fragment*/
00674     if((uip_ntohs(UIP_FRAG_BUF->offsetresmore) & IP_MF) == 0) {
00675       uip_reassflags |= UIP_REASS_FLAG_LASTFRAG;
00676       /*calculate the size of the entire packet*/
00677       uip_reasslen = offset + len;
00678       PRINTF("LAST FRAGMENT reasslen %d\n", uip_reasslen);
00679     } else {
00680       /* If len is not a multiple of 8 octets and the M flag of that fragment
00681          is 1, then that fragment must be discarded and an ICMP Parameter
00682          Problem, Code 0, message should be sent to the source of the fragment,
00683          pointing to the Payload Length field of the fragment packet. */
00684       if(len % 8 != 0){
00685         uip_icmp6_error_output(ICMP6_PARAM_PROB, ICMP6_PARAMPROB_HEADER, 4);
00686         uip_reassflags |= UIP_REASS_FLAG_ERROR_MSG;
00687         /* not clear if we should interrupt reassembly, but it seems so from
00688            the conformance tests */
00689         uip_reass_on = 0;
00690         etimer_stop(&uip_reass_timer);
00691         return uip_len;
00692       }
00693     }
00694     
00695     /* Copy the fragment into the reassembly buffer, at the right
00696        offset. */
00697     memcpy((uint8_t *)FBUF + UIP_IPH_LEN + uip_ext_len + offset,
00698            (uint8_t *)UIP_FRAG_BUF + UIP_FRAGH_LEN, len);
00699     
00700     /* Update the bitmap. */
00701     if(offset >> 6 == (offset + len) >> 6) {
00702       uip_reassbitmap[offset >> 6] |=
00703         bitmap_bits[(offset >> 3) & 7] &
00704         ~bitmap_bits[((offset + len) >> 3)  & 7];
00705     } else {
00706       /* If the two endpoints are in different bytes, we update the
00707          bytes in the endpoints and fill the stuff inbetween with
00708          0xff. */
00709       uip_reassbitmap[offset >> 6] |= bitmap_bits[(offset >> 3) & 7];
00710  
00711       for(i = (1 + (offset >> 6)); i < ((offset + len) >> 6); ++i) {
00712         uip_reassbitmap[i] = 0xff;
00713       }
00714       uip_reassbitmap[(offset + len) >> 6] |=
00715         ~bitmap_bits[((offset + len) >> 3) & 7];
00716     }
00717   
00718     /* Finally, we check if we have a full packet in the buffer. We do
00719        this by checking if we have the last fragment and if all bits
00720        in the bitmap are set. */
00721     
00722     if(uip_reassflags & UIP_REASS_FLAG_LASTFRAG) {
00723       /* Check all bytes up to and including all but the last byte in
00724          the bitmap. */
00725       for(i = 0; i < (uip_reasslen >> 6); ++i) {
00726         if(uip_reassbitmap[i] != 0xff) {
00727           return 0;
00728         }
00729       }
00730       /* Check the last byte in the bitmap. It should contain just the
00731          right amount of bits. */
00732       if(uip_reassbitmap[uip_reasslen >> 6] !=
00733          (u8_t)~bitmap_bits[(uip_reasslen >> 3) & 7]) {
00734         return 0;
00735       }
00736 
00737      /* If we have come this far, we have a full packet in the
00738          buffer, so we copy it to uip_buf. We also reset the timer. */
00739       uip_reass_on = 0;
00740       etimer_stop(&uip_reass_timer);
00741 
00742       uip_reasslen += UIP_IPH_LEN + uip_ext_len;
00743       memcpy(UIP_IP_BUF, FBUF, uip_reasslen);
00744       UIP_IP_BUF->len[0] = ((uip_reasslen - UIP_IPH_LEN) >> 8);
00745       UIP_IP_BUF->len[1] = ((uip_reasslen - UIP_IPH_LEN) & 0xff);
00746       PRINTF("REASSEMBLED PAQUET %d (%d)\n", uip_reasslen,
00747              (UIP_IP_BUF->len[0] << 8) | UIP_IP_BUF->len[1]);
00748    
00749       return uip_reasslen;
00750       
00751     }
00752   } else {
00753     PRINTF("Already reassembling another paquet\n");
00754   }
00755   return 0;
00756 }
00757 
00758 void
00759 uip_reass_over(void)
00760 {
00761    /* to late, we abandon the reassembly of the packet */
00762 
00763   uip_reass_on = 0;
00764   etimer_stop(&uip_reass_timer);
00765 
00766   if(uip_reassflags & UIP_REASS_FLAG_FIRSTFRAG){
00767     PRINTF("FRAG INTERRUPTED TOO LATE\n");
00768     /* If the first fragment has been received, an ICMP Time Exceeded
00769        -- Fragment Reassembly Time Exceeded message should be sent to the
00770        source of that fragment. */
00771     /** \note
00772      * We don't have a complete packet to put in the error message.
00773      * We could include the first fragment but since its not mandated by
00774      * any RFC, we decided not to include it as it reduces the size of
00775      * the packet.
00776      */
00777     uip_len = 0;
00778     uip_ext_len = 0;
00779     memcpy(UIP_IP_BUF, FBUF, UIP_IPH_LEN); /* copy the header for src
00780                                               and dest address*/
00781     uip_icmp6_error_output(ICMP6_TIME_EXCEEDED, ICMP6_TIME_EXCEED_REASSEMBLY, 0);
00782     
00783     UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.ip.sent);
00784     uip_flags = 0;
00785   }
00786 }
00787 
00788 #endif /* UIP_CONF_IPV6_REASSEMBLY */
00789 
00790 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00791 #if UIP_TCP
00792 static void
00793 uip_add_rcv_nxt(u16_t n)
00794 {
00795   uip_add32(uip_conn->rcv_nxt, n);
00796   uip_conn->rcv_nxt[0] = uip_acc32[0];
00797   uip_conn->rcv_nxt[1] = uip_acc32[1];
00798   uip_conn->rcv_nxt[2] = uip_acc32[2];
00799   uip_conn->rcv_nxt[3] = uip_acc32[3];
00800 }
00801 #endif
00802 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00803 
00804 /**
00805  * \brief Process the options in Destination and Hop By Hop extension headers
00806  */
00807 static u8_t
00808 ext_hdr_options_process(void)
00809 {
00810  /*
00811   * Length field in the extension header: length of the header in units of
00812   * 8 bytes, excluding the first 8 bytes
00813   * length field in an option : the length of data in the option
00814   */
00815   uip_ext_opt_offset = 2;
00816   while(uip_ext_opt_offset < ((UIP_EXT_BUF->len << 3) + 8)) {
00817     switch(UIP_EXT_HDR_OPT_BUF->type) {
00818       /*
00819        * for now we do not support any options except padding ones
00820        * PAD1 does not make sense as the header must be 8bytes aligned,
00821        * hence we can only have
00822        */
00823       case UIP_EXT_HDR_OPT_PAD1:
00824         PRINTF("Processing PAD1 option\n");
00825         uip_ext_opt_offset += 1;
00826         break;
00827       case UIP_EXT_HDR_OPT_PADN:
00828         PRINTF("Processing PADN option\n");
00829         uip_ext_opt_offset += UIP_EXT_HDR_OPT_PADN_BUF->opt_len + 2;
00830         break;
00831       default:
00832         /*
00833          * check the two highest order bits of the option
00834          * - 00 skip over this option and continue processing the header.
00835          * - 01 discard the packet.
00836          * - 10 discard the packet and, regardless of whether or not the
00837          *   packet's Destination Address was a multicast address, send an
00838          *   ICMP Parameter Problem, Code 2, message to the packet's
00839          *   Source Address, pointing to the unrecognized Option Type.
00840          * - 11 discard the packet and, only if the packet's Destination
00841          *   Address was not a multicast address, send an ICMP Parameter
00842          *   Problem, Code 2, message to the packet's Source Address,
00843          *   pointing to the unrecognized Option Type.
00844          */
00845         PRINTF("MSB %x\n", UIP_EXT_HDR_OPT_BUF->type);
00846         switch(UIP_EXT_HDR_OPT_BUF->type & 0xC0) {
00847           case 0:
00848             break;
00849           case 0x40:
00850             return 1;
00851           case 0xC0:
00852             if(uip_is_addr_mcast(&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr)) {
00853               return 1;
00854             }
00855           case 0x80:
00856             uip_icmp6_error_output(ICMP6_PARAM_PROB, ICMP6_PARAMPROB_OPTION,
00857                              (u32_t)UIP_IPH_LEN + uip_ext_len + uip_ext_opt_offset);
00858             return 2;
00859         }
00860         /* in the cases were we did not discard, update ext_opt* */
00861         uip_ext_opt_offset += UIP_EXT_HDR_OPT_BUF->len + 2;
00862         break;
00863     }
00864   }
00865   return 0;
00866 }
00867 
00868 
00869 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00870 void
00871 uip_process(u8_t flag)
00872 {
00873 #if UIP_TCP
00874   register struct uip_conn *uip_connr = uip_conn;
00875 #endif /* UIP_TCP */
00876 #if UIP_UDP
00877   if(flag == UIP_UDP_SEND_CONN) {
00878     goto udp_send;
00879   }
00880 #endif /* UIP_UDP */
00881   uip_sappdata = uip_appdata = &uip_buf[UIP_IPTCPH_LEN + UIP_LLH_LEN];
00882    
00883   /* Check if we were invoked because of a poll request for a
00884      particular connection. */
00885   if(flag == UIP_POLL_REQUEST) {
00886 #if UIP_TCP
00887     if((uip_connr->tcpstateflags & UIP_TS_MASK) == UIP_ESTABLISHED &&
00888        !uip_outstanding(uip_connr)) {
00889       uip_flags = UIP_POLL;
00890       UIP_APPCALL();
00891       goto appsend;
00892 #if UIP_ACTIVE_OPEN
00893     } else if((uip_connr->tcpstateflags & UIP_TS_MASK) == UIP_SYN_SENT) {
00894       /* In the SYN_SENT state, we retransmit out SYN. */
00895       UIP_TCP_BUF->flags = 0;
00896       goto tcp_send_syn;
00897 #endif /* UIP_ACTIVE_OPEN */
00898     }
00899     goto drop;
00900 #endif /* UIP_TCP */
00901     /* Check if we were invoked because of the perodic timer fireing. */
00902   } else if(flag == UIP_TIMER) {
00903     /* Reset the length variables. */
00904 #if UIP_TCP
00905     uip_len = 0;
00906     uip_slen = 0;
00907     
00908     /* Increase the initial sequence number. */
00909     if(++iss[3] == 0) {
00910       if(++iss[2] == 0) {
00911         if(++iss[1] == 0) {
00912           ++iss[0];
00913         }
00914       }
00915     }
00916     
00917     /*
00918      * Check if the connection is in a state in which we simply wait
00919      * for the connection to time out. If so, we increase the
00920      * connection's timer and remove the connection if it times
00921      * out.
00922      */
00923     if(uip_connr->tcpstateflags == UIP_TIME_WAIT ||
00924        uip_connr->tcpstateflags == UIP_FIN_WAIT_2) {
00925       ++(uip_connr->timer);
00926       if(uip_connr->timer == UIP_TIME_WAIT_TIMEOUT) {
00927         uip_connr->tcpstateflags = UIP_CLOSED;
00928       }
00929     } else if(uip_connr->tcpstateflags != UIP_CLOSED) {
00930       /*
00931        * If the connection has outstanding data, we increase the
00932        * connection's timer and see if it has reached the RTO value
00933        * in which case we retransmit.
00934        */
00935       if(uip_outstanding(uip_connr)) {
00936         if(uip_connr->timer-- == 0) {
00937           if(uip_connr->nrtx == UIP_MAXRTX ||
00938              ((uip_connr->tcpstateflags == UIP_SYN_SENT ||
00939                uip_connr->tcpstateflags == UIP_SYN_RCVD) &&
00940               uip_connr->nrtx == UIP_MAXSYNRTX)) {
00941             uip_connr->tcpstateflags = UIP_CLOSED;
00942                   
00943             /*
00944              * We call UIP_APPCALL() with uip_flags set to
00945              * UIP_TIMEDOUT to inform the application that the
00946              * connection has timed out.
00947              */
00948             uip_flags = UIP_TIMEDOUT;
00949             UIP_APPCALL();
00950                   
00951             /* We also send a reset packet to the remote host. */
00952             UIP_TCP_BUF->flags = TCP_RST | TCP_ACK;
00953             goto tcp_send_nodata;
00954           }
00955                
00956           /* Exponential backoff. */
00957           uip_connr->timer = UIP_RTO << (uip_connr->nrtx > 4?
00958                                          4:
00959                                          uip_connr->nrtx);
00960           ++(uip_connr->nrtx);
00961                
00962           /*
00963            * Ok, so we need to retransmit. We do this differently
00964            * depending on which state we are in. In ESTABLISHED, we
00965            * call upon the application so that it may prepare the
00966            * data for the retransmit. In SYN_RCVD, we resend the
00967            * SYNACK that we sent earlier and in LAST_ACK we have to
00968            * retransmit our FINACK.
00969            */
00970           UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.tcp.rexmit);
00971           switch(uip_connr->tcpstateflags & UIP_TS_MASK) {
00972             case UIP_SYN_RCVD:
00973               /* In the SYN_RCVD state, we should retransmit our SYNACK. */
00974               goto tcp_send_synack;
00975                      
00976 #if UIP_ACTIVE_OPEN
00977             case UIP_SYN_SENT:
00978               /* In the SYN_SENT state, we retransmit out SYN. */
00979               UIP_TCP_BUF->flags = 0;
00980               goto tcp_send_syn;
00981 #endif /* UIP_ACTIVE_OPEN */
00982                      
00983             case UIP_ESTABLISHED:
00984               /*
00985                * In the ESTABLISHED state, we call upon the application
00986                * to do the actual retransmit after which we jump into
00987                * the code for sending out the packet (the apprexmit
00988                * label).
00989                */
00990               uip_flags = UIP_REXMIT;
00991               UIP_APPCALL();
00992               goto apprexmit;
00993                      
00994             case UIP_FIN_WAIT_1:
00995             case UIP_CLOSING:
00996             case UIP_LAST_ACK:
00997               /* In all these states we should retransmit a FINACK. */
00998               goto tcp_send_finack;
00999           }
01000         }
01001       } else if((uip_connr->tcpstateflags & UIP_TS_MASK) == UIP_ESTABLISHED) {
01002         /*
01003          * If there was no need for a retransmission, we poll the
01004          * application for new data.
01005          */
01006         uip_flags = UIP_POLL;
01007         UIP_APPCALL();
01008         goto appsend;
01009       }
01010     }
01011     goto drop;
01012 #endif /* UIP_TCP */
01013   }
01014 #if UIP_UDP
01015   if(flag == UIP_UDP_TIMER) {
01016     if(uip_udp_conn->lport != 0) {
01017       uip_conn = NULL;
01018       uip_sappdata = uip_appdata = &uip_buf[UIP_LLH_LEN + UIP_IPUDPH_LEN];
01019       uip_len = uip_slen = 0;
01020       uip_flags = UIP_POLL;
01021       UIP_UDP_APPCALL();
01022       goto udp_send;
01023     } else {
01024       goto drop;
01025     }
01026   }
01027 #endif /* UIP_UDP */
01028 
01029   
01030   /* This is where the input processing starts. */
01031   UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.ip.recv);
01032    
01033   /* Start of IP input header processing code. */
01034    
01035   /* Check validity of the IP header. */
01036   if((UIP_IP_BUF->vtc & 0xf0) != 0x60)  { /* IP version and header length. */
01037     UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.ip.drop);
01038     UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.ip.vhlerr);
01039     UIP_LOG("ipv6: invalid version.");
01040     goto drop;
01041   }
01042   /*
01043    * Check the size of the packet. If the size reported to us in
01044    * uip_len is smaller the size reported in the IP header, we assume
01045    * that the packet has been corrupted in transit. If the size of
01046    * uip_len is larger than the size reported in the IP packet header,
01047    * the packet has been padded and we set uip_len to the correct
01048    * value..
01049    */
01050    
01051   if((UIP_IP_BUF->len[0] << 8) + UIP_IP_BUF->len[1] <= uip_len) {
01052     uip_len = (UIP_IP_BUF->len[0] << 8) + UIP_IP_BUF->len[1] + UIP_IPH_LEN;
01053     /*
01054      * The length reported in the IPv6 header is the
01055      * length of the payload that follows the
01056      * header. However, uIP uses the uip_len variable
01057      * for holding the size of the entire packet,
01058      * including the IP header. For IPv4 this is not a
01059      * problem as the length field in the IPv4 header
01060      * contains the length of the entire packet. But
01061      * for IPv6 we need to add the size of the IPv6
01062      * header (40 bytes).
01063      */
01064   } else {
01065     UIP_LOG("ip: packet shorter than reported in IP header.");
01066     goto drop;
01067   }
01068   
01069   PRINTF("IPv6 packet received from ");
01070   PRINT6ADDR(&UIP_IP_BUF->srcipaddr);
01071   PRINTF(" to ");
01072   PRINT6ADDR(&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr);
01073   PRINTF("\n");
01074 
01075   if(uip_is_addr_mcast(&UIP_IP_BUF->srcipaddr)){
01076     UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.ip.drop);
01077     PRINTF("Dropping packet, src is mcast\n");
01078     goto drop;
01079   }
01080 
01081 #if UIP_CONF_ROUTER
01082   /* TBD Some Parameter problem messages */
01083   if(!uip_ds6_is_my_addr(&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr) &&
01084      !uip_ds6_is_my_maddr(&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr)) {
01085     if(!uip_is_addr_mcast(&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr) &&
01086        !uip_is_addr_link_local(&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr) &&
01087        !uip_is_addr_link_local(&UIP_IP_BUF->srcipaddr) &&
01088        !uip_is_addr_unspecified(&UIP_IP_BUF->srcipaddr) &&
01089        !uip_is_addr_loopback(&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr)) {
01090 
01091 
01092       /* Check MTU */
01093       if(uip_len > UIP_LINK_MTU) {
01094         uip_icmp6_error_output(ICMP6_PACKET_TOO_BIG, 0, UIP_LINK_MTU);
01095         UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.ip.drop);
01096         goto send;
01097       }
01098       /* Check Hop Limit */
01099       if(UIP_IP_BUF->ttl <= 1) {
01100         uip_icmp6_error_output(ICMP6_TIME_EXCEEDED,
01101                                ICMP6_TIME_EXCEED_TRANSIT, 0);
01102         UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.ip.drop);
01103         goto send;
01104       }
01105       UIP_IP_BUF->ttl = UIP_IP_BUF->ttl - 1;
01106       PRINTF("Forwarding packet to ");
01107       PRINT6ADDR(&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr);
01108       PRINTF("\n");
01109       UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.ip.forwarded);
01110       goto send;
01111     } else {
01112       if((uip_is_addr_link_local(&UIP_IP_BUF->srcipaddr)) &&
01113          (!uip_is_addr_unspecified(&UIP_IP_BUF->srcipaddr)) &&
01114          (!uip_is_addr_loopback(&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr)) &&
01115          (!uip_is_addr_mcast(&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr)) &&
01116          (!uip_ds6_is_addr_onlink((&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr)))) {
01117         PRINTF("LL source address with off link destination, dropping\n");
01118         uip_icmp6_error_output(ICMP6_DST_UNREACH,
01119                                ICMP6_DST_UNREACH_NOTNEIGHBOR, 0);
01120         goto send;
01121       }
01122       PRINTF("Dropping packet, not for me and link local or multicast\n");
01123       UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.ip.drop);
01124       goto drop;
01125     }
01126   }
01127 #else /* UIP_CONF_ROUTER */
01128   if(!uip_ds6_is_my_addr(&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr) &&
01129      !uip_ds6_is_my_maddr(&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr) &&
01130      !uip_is_addr_mcast(&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr)) {
01131     PRINTF("Dropping packet, not for me\n");
01132     UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.ip.drop);
01133     goto drop;
01134   }
01135 #endif /* UIP_CONF_ROUTER */
01136 
01137   /*
01138    * Next header field processing. In IPv6, we can have extension headers,
01139    * they are processed here
01140    */
01141   uip_next_hdr = &UIP_IP_BUF->proto;
01142   uip_ext_len = 0;
01143   uip_ext_bitmap = 0;
01144   while(1) {
01145     switch(*uip_next_hdr){
01146 #if UIP_TCP
01147       case UIP_PROTO_TCP:
01148         /* TCP, for both IPv4 and IPv6 */
01149         goto tcp_input;
01150 #endif /* UIP_TCP */
01151 #if UIP_UDP
01152       case UIP_PROTO_UDP:
01153         /* UDP, for both IPv4 and IPv6 */
01154         goto udp_input;
01155 #endif /* UIP_UDP */
01156       case UIP_PROTO_ICMP6:
01157         /* ICMPv6 */
01158         goto icmp6_input;
01159       case UIP_PROTO_HBHO:
01160         PRINTF("Processing hbh header\n");
01161         /* Hop by hop option header */
01162 #if UIP_CONF_IPV6_CHECKS
01163         /* Hop by hop option header. If we saw one HBH already, drop */
01164         if(uip_ext_bitmap & UIP_EXT_HDR_BITMAP_HBHO) {
01165           goto bad_hdr;
01166         } else {
01167           uip_ext_bitmap |= UIP_EXT_HDR_BITMAP_HBHO;
01168         }
01169 #endif /*UIP_CONF_IPV6_CHECKS*/
01170         switch(ext_hdr_options_process()) {
01171           case 0:
01172             /*continue*/
01173             uip_next_hdr = &UIP_EXT_BUF->next;
01174             uip_ext_len += (UIP_EXT_BUF->len << 3) + 8;
01175             break;
01176           case 1:
01177             /*silently discard*/
01178             goto drop;
01179           case 2:
01180             /* send icmp error message (created in ext_hdr_options_process)
01181              * and discard*/
01182             goto send;
01183         }
01184         break;
01185       case UIP_PROTO_DESTO:
01186 #if UIP_CONF_IPV6_CHECKS
01187         /* Destination option header. if we saw two already, drop */
01188         PRINTF("Processing desto header\n");
01189         if(uip_ext_bitmap & UIP_EXT_HDR_BITMAP_DESTO1) {
01190           if(uip_ext_bitmap & UIP_EXT_HDR_BITMAP_DESTO2) {
01191             goto bad_hdr;
01192           } else{
01193             uip_ext_bitmap |= UIP_EXT_HDR_BITMAP_DESTO2;
01194           }
01195         } else {
01196           uip_ext_bitmap |= UIP_EXT_HDR_BITMAP_DESTO1;
01197         }
01198 #endif /*UIP_CONF_IPV6_CHECKS*/
01199         switch(ext_hdr_options_process()) {
01200           case 0:
01201             /*continue*/
01202             uip_next_hdr = &UIP_EXT_BUF->next;
01203             uip_ext_len += (UIP_EXT_BUF->len << 3) + 8;
01204             break;
01205           case 1:
01206             /*silently discard*/
01207             goto drop;
01208           case 2:
01209             /* send icmp error message (created in ext_hdr_options_process)
01210              * and discard*/
01211             goto send;
01212         }
01213         break;
01214       case UIP_PROTO_ROUTING:
01215 #if UIP_CONF_IPV6_CHECKS
01216         /* Routing header. If we saw one already, drop */
01217         if(uip_ext_bitmap & UIP_EXT_HDR_BITMAP_ROUTING) {
01218           goto bad_hdr;
01219         } else {
01220           uip_ext_bitmap |= UIP_EXT_HDR_BITMAP_ROUTING;
01221         }
01222 #endif /*UIP_CONF_IPV6_CHECKS*/
01223         /*
01224          * Routing Header  length field is in units of 8 bytes, excluding
01225          * As per RFC2460 section 4.4, if routing type is unrecognized:
01226          * if segments left = 0, ignore the header
01227          * if segments left > 0, discard packet and send icmp error pointing
01228          * to the routing type
01229          */
01230 
01231         PRINTF("Processing Routing header\n");
01232         if(UIP_ROUTING_BUF->seg_left > 0) {
01233           uip_icmp6_error_output(ICMP6_PARAM_PROB, ICMP6_PARAMPROB_HEADER, UIP_IPH_LEN + uip_ext_len + 2);
01234           UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.ip.drop);
01235           UIP_LOG("ip6: unrecognized routing type");
01236           goto send;
01237         }
01238         uip_next_hdr = &UIP_EXT_BUF->next;
01239         uip_ext_len += (UIP_EXT_BUF->len << 3) + 8;
01240         break;
01241       case UIP_PROTO_FRAG:
01242         /* Fragmentation header:call the reassembly function, then leave */
01243 #if UIP_CONF_IPV6_REASSEMBLY
01244         PRINTF("Processing frag header\n");
01245         uip_len = uip_reass();
01246         if(uip_len == 0) {
01247           goto drop;
01248         }
01249         if(uip_reassflags & UIP_REASS_FLAG_ERROR_MSG){
01250           /* we are not done with reassembly, this is an error message */
01251           goto send;
01252         }
01253         /*packet is reassembled, reset the next hdr to the beginning
01254            of the IP header and restart the parsing of the reassembled pkt*/
01255         PRINTF("Processing reassembled packet\n");
01256         uip_ext_len = 0;
01257         uip_ext_bitmap = 0;
01258         uip_next_hdr = &UIP_IP_BUF->proto;
01259         break;
01260 #else /* UIP_CONF_IPV6_REASSEMBLY */
01261         UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.ip.drop);
01262         UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.ip.fragerr);
01263         UIP_LOG("ip: fragment dropped.");
01264         goto drop;
01265 #endif /* UIP_CONF_IPV6_REASSEMBLY */
01266       case UIP_PROTO_NONE:
01267         goto drop;
01268       default:
01269         goto bad_hdr;
01270     }
01271   }
01272   bad_hdr:
01273   /*
01274    * RFC 2460 send error message parameterr problem, code unrecognized
01275    * next header, pointing to the next header field
01276    */
01277   uip_icmp6_error_output(ICMP6_PARAM_PROB, ICMP6_PARAMPROB_NEXTHEADER, (u32_t)(uip_next_hdr - (uint8_t *)UIP_IP_BUF));
01278   UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.ip.drop);
01279   UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.ip.protoerr);
01280   UIP_LOG("ip6: unrecognized header");
01281   goto send;
01282   /* End of headers processing */
01283   
01284   icmp6_input:
01285   /* This is IPv6 ICMPv6 processing code. */
01286   PRINTF("icmp6_input: length %d\n", uip_len);
01287 
01288 #if UIP_CONF_IPV6_CHECKS
01289   /* Compute and check the ICMP header checksum */
01290   if(uip_icmp6chksum() != 0xffff) {
01291     UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.icmp.drop);
01292     UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.icmp.chkerr);
01293     UIP_LOG("icmpv6: bad checksum.");
01294     goto drop;
01295   }
01296 #endif /*UIP_CONF_IPV6_CHECKS*/
01297 
01298   UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.icmp.recv);
01299   /*
01300    * Here we process incoming ICMPv6 packets
01301    * For echo request, we send echo reply
01302    * For ND pkts, we call the appropriate function in uip-nd6.c
01303    * We do not treat Error messages for now
01304    * If no pkt is to be sent as an answer to the incoming one, we
01305    * "goto drop". Else we just break; then at the after the "switch"
01306    * we "goto send"
01307    */
01308 #if UIP_CONF_ICMP6
01309   UIP_ICMP6_APPCALL(UIP_ICMP_BUF->type);
01310 #endif /*UIP_CONF_ICMP6*/
01311 
01312   switch(UIP_ICMP_BUF->type) {
01313     case ICMP6_NS:
01314       uip_nd6_ns_input();
01315       break;
01316     case ICMP6_NA:
01317       uip_nd6_na_input();
01318       break;
01319     case ICMP6_RS:
01320 #if UIP_CONF_ROUTER && UIP_ND6_SEND_RA
01321     uip_nd6_rs_input();
01322 #else /* UIP_CONF_ROUTER && UIP_ND6_SEND_RA */
01323     UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.icmp.drop);
01324     uip_len = 0;
01325 #endif /* UIP_CONF_ROUTER && UIP_ND6_SEND_RA */
01326     break;
01327   case ICMP6_RA:
01328 #if UIP_CONF_ROUTER
01329     UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.icmp.drop);
01330     uip_len = 0;
01331 #else /* UIP_CONF_ROUTER */
01332     uip_nd6_ra_input();
01333 #endif /* UIP_CONF_ROUTER */
01334     break;
01335 #if UIP_CONF_IPV6_RPL
01336   case ICMP6_RPL:
01337     uip_rpl_input();
01338     break;
01339 #endif /* UIP_CONF_IPV6_RPL */
01340     case ICMP6_ECHO_REQUEST:
01341       uip_icmp6_echo_request_input();
01342       break;
01343     case ICMP6_ECHO_REPLY:
01344       /** \note We don't implement any application callback for now */
01345       PRINTF("Received an icmp6 echo reply\n");
01346       UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.icmp.recv);
01347       uip_len = 0;
01348       break;
01349     default:
01350       PRINTF("Unknown icmp6 message type %d\n", UIP_ICMP_BUF->type);
01351       UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.icmp.drop);
01352       UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.icmp.typeerr);
01353       UIP_LOG("icmp6: unknown ICMP message.");
01354       uip_len = 0;
01355       break;
01356   }
01357   
01358   if(uip_len > 0) {
01359     goto send;
01360   } else {
01361     goto drop;
01362   }
01363   /* End of IPv6 ICMP processing. */
01364    
01365 
01366 #if UIP_UDP
01367   /* UDP input processing. */
01368  udp_input:
01369   PRINTF("Receiving UDP packet\n");
01370   UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.udp.recv);
01371  
01372   /* UDP processing is really just a hack. We don't do anything to the
01373      UDP/IP headers, but let the UDP application do all the hard
01374      work. If the application sets uip_slen, it has a packet to
01375      send. */
01376 #if UIP_UDP_CHECKSUMS
01377   uip_len = uip_len - UIP_IPUDPH_LEN;
01378   uip_appdata = &uip_buf[UIP_LLH_LEN + UIP_IPUDPH_LEN];
01379   if(UIP_UDP_BUF->udpchksum != 0 && uip_udpchksum() != 0xffff) {
01380     UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.udp.drop);
01381     UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.udp.chkerr);
01382     PRINTF("udp: bad checksum 0x%04x 0x%04x\n", UIP_UDP_BUF->udpchksum,
01383            uip_udpchksum());
01384     goto drop;
01385   }
01386 #else /* UIP_UDP_CHECKSUMS */
01387   uip_len = uip_len - UIP_IPUDPH_LEN;
01388 #endif /* UIP_UDP_CHECKSUMS */
01389 
01390   /* Make sure that the UDP destination port number is not zero. */
01391   if(UIP_UDP_BUF->destport == 0) {
01392     PRINTF("udp: zero port.\n");
01393     goto drop;
01394   }
01395 
01396   /* Demultiplex this UDP packet between the UDP "connections". */
01397   for(uip_udp_conn = &uip_udp_conns[0];
01398       uip_udp_conn < &uip_udp_conns[UIP_UDP_CONNS];
01399       ++uip_udp_conn) {
01400     /* If the local UDP port is non-zero, the connection is considered
01401        to be used. If so, the local port number is checked against the
01402        destination port number in the received packet. If the two port
01403        numbers match, the remote port number is checked if the
01404        connection is bound to a remote port. Finally, if the
01405        connection is bound to a remote IP address, the source IP
01406        address of the packet is checked. */
01407     if(uip_udp_conn->lport != 0 &&
01408        UIP_UDP_BUF->destport == uip_udp_conn->lport &&
01409        (uip_udp_conn->rport == 0 ||
01410         UIP_UDP_BUF->srcport == uip_udp_conn->rport) &&
01411        (uip_is_addr_unspecified(&uip_udp_conn->ripaddr) ||
01412         uip_ipaddr_cmp(&UIP_IP_BUF->srcipaddr, &uip_udp_conn->ripaddr))) {
01413       goto udp_found;
01414     }
01415   }
01416   PRINTF("udp: no matching connection found\n");
01417 
01418 #if UIP_UDP_SEND_UNREACH_NOPORT
01419   uip_icmp6_error_output(ICMP6_DST_UNREACH, ICMP6_DST_UNREACH_NOPORT, 0);
01420   UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.ip.drop);
01421   goto send;
01422 #else
01423   goto drop;
01424 #endif
01425 
01426  udp_found:
01427   PRINTF("In udp_found\n");
01428  
01429   uip_conn = NULL;
01430   uip_flags = UIP_NEWDATA;
01431   uip_sappdata = uip_appdata = &uip_buf[UIP_LLH_LEN + UIP_IPUDPH_LEN];
01432   uip_slen = 0;
01433   UIP_UDP_APPCALL();
01434 
01435  udp_send:
01436   PRINTF("In udp_send\n");
01437 
01438   if(uip_slen == 0) {
01439     goto drop;
01440   }
01441   uip_len = uip_slen + UIP_IPUDPH_LEN;
01442 
01443   /* For IPv6, the IP length field does not include the IPv6 IP header
01444      length. */
01445   UIP_IP_BUF->len[0] = ((uip_len - UIP_IPH_LEN) >> 8);
01446   UIP_IP_BUF->len[1] = ((uip_len - UIP_IPH_LEN) & 0xff);
01447 
01448   UIP_IP_BUF->ttl = uip_udp_conn->ttl;
01449   UIP_IP_BUF->proto = UIP_PROTO_UDP;
01450 
01451   UIP_UDP_BUF->udplen = UIP_HTONS(uip_slen + UIP_UDPH_LEN);
01452   UIP_UDP_BUF->udpchksum = 0;
01453 
01454   UIP_UDP_BUF->srcport  = uip_udp_conn->lport;
01455   UIP_UDP_BUF->destport = uip_udp_conn->rport;
01456 
01457   uip_ipaddr_copy(&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr, &uip_udp_conn->ripaddr);
01458   uip_ds6_select_src(&UIP_IP_BUF->srcipaddr, &UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr);
01459 
01460   uip_appdata = &uip_buf[UIP_LLH_LEN + UIP_IPTCPH_LEN];
01461 
01462 #if UIP_UDP_CHECKSUMS
01463   /* Calculate UDP checksum. */
01464   UIP_UDP_BUF->udpchksum = ~(uip_udpchksum());
01465   if(UIP_UDP_BUF->udpchksum == 0) {
01466     UIP_UDP_BUF->udpchksum = 0xffff;
01467   }
01468 #endif /* UIP_UDP_CHECKSUMS */
01469   UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.udp.sent);
01470   goto ip_send_nolen;
01471 #endif /* UIP_UDP */
01472 
01473 #if UIP_TCP
01474   /* TCP input processing. */
01475  tcp_input:
01476 
01477   UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.tcp.recv);
01478   PRINTF("Receiving TCP packet\n");
01479   /* Start of TCP input header processing code. */
01480   
01481   if(uip_tcpchksum() != 0xffff) {   /* Compute and check the TCP
01482                                        checksum. */
01483     UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.tcp.drop);
01484     UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.tcp.chkerr);
01485     UIP_LOG("tcp: bad checksum.");
01486     goto drop;
01487   }
01488 
01489   /* Make sure that the TCP port number is not zero. */
01490   if(UIP_TCP_BUF->destport == 0 || UIP_TCP_BUF->srcport == 0) {
01491     UIP_LOG("tcp: zero port.");
01492     goto drop;
01493   }
01494 
01495   /* Demultiplex this segment. */
01496   /* First check any active connections. */
01497   for(uip_connr = &uip_conns[0]; uip_connr <= &uip_conns[UIP_CONNS - 1];
01498       ++uip_connr) {
01499     if(uip_connr->tcpstateflags != UIP_CLOSED &&
01500        UIP_TCP_BUF->destport == uip_connr->lport &&
01501        UIP_TCP_BUF->srcport == uip_connr->rport &&
01502        uip_ipaddr_cmp(&UIP_IP_BUF->srcipaddr, &uip_connr->ripaddr)) {
01503       goto found;
01504     }
01505   }
01506 
01507   /* If we didn't find and active connection that expected the packet,
01508      either this packet is an old duplicate, or this is a SYN packet
01509      destined for a connection in LISTEN. If the SYN flag isn't set,
01510      it is an old packet and we send a RST. */
01511   if((UIP_TCP_BUF->flags & TCP_CTL) != TCP_SYN) {
01512     goto reset;
01513   }
01514   
01515   tmp16 = UIP_TCP_BUF->destport;
01516   /* Next, check listening connections. */
01517   for(c = 0; c < UIP_LISTENPORTS; ++c) {
01518     if(tmp16 == uip_listenports[c]) {
01519       goto found_listen;
01520     }
01521   }
01522   
01523   /* No matching connection found, so we send a RST packet. */
01524   UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.tcp.synrst);
01525 
01526  reset:
01527   PRINTF("In reset\n");
01528   /* We do not send resets in response to resets. */
01529   if(UIP_TCP_BUF->flags & TCP_RST) {
01530     goto drop;
01531   }
01532 
01533   UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.tcp.rst);
01534   
01535   UIP_TCP_BUF->flags = TCP_RST | TCP_ACK;
01536   uip_len = UIP_IPTCPH_LEN;
01537   UIP_TCP_BUF->tcpoffset = 5 << 4;
01538 
01539   /* Flip the seqno and ackno fields in the TCP header. */
01540   c = UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[3];
01541   UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[3] = UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[3];
01542   UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[3] = c;
01543   
01544   c = UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[2];
01545   UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[2] = UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[2];
01546   UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[2] = c;
01547   
01548   c = UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[1];
01549   UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[1] = UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[1];
01550   UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[1] = c;
01551   
01552   c = UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[0];
01553   UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[0] = UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[0];
01554   UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[0] = c;
01555 
01556   /* We also have to increase the sequence number we are
01557      acknowledging. If the least significant byte overflowed, we need
01558      to propagate the carry to the other bytes as well. */
01559   if(++UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[3] == 0) {
01560     if(++UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[2] == 0) {
01561       if(++UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[1] == 0) {
01562         ++UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[0];
01563       }
01564     }
01565   }
01566  
01567   /* Swap port numbers. */
01568   tmp16 = UIP_TCP_BUF->srcport;
01569   UIP_TCP_BUF->srcport = UIP_TCP_BUF->destport;
01570   UIP_TCP_BUF->destport = tmp16;
01571   
01572   /* Swap IP addresses. */
01573   uip_ipaddr_copy(&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr, &UIP_IP_BUF->srcipaddr);
01574   uip_ds6_select_src(&UIP_IP_BUF->srcipaddr, &UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr);
01575   /* And send out the RST packet! */
01576   goto tcp_send_noconn;
01577 
01578   /* This label will be jumped to if we matched the incoming packet
01579      with a connection in LISTEN. In that case, we should create a new
01580      connection and send a SYNACK in return. */
01581  found_listen:
01582   PRINTF("In found listen\n");
01583   /* First we check if there are any connections avaliable. Unused
01584      connections are kept in the same table as used connections, but
01585      unused ones have the tcpstate set to CLOSED. Also, connections in
01586      TIME_WAIT are kept track of and we'll use the oldest one if no
01587      CLOSED connections are found. Thanks to Eddie C. Dost for a very
01588      nice algorithm for the TIME_WAIT search. */
01589   uip_connr = 0;
01590   for(c = 0; c < UIP_CONNS; ++c) {
01591     if(uip_conns[c].tcpstateflags == UIP_CLOSED) {
01592       uip_connr = &uip_conns[c];
01593       break;
01594     }
01595     if(uip_conns[c].tcpstateflags == UIP_TIME_WAIT) {
01596       if(uip_connr == 0 ||
01597          uip_conns[c].timer > uip_connr->timer) {
01598         uip_connr = &uip_conns[c];
01599       }
01600     }
01601   }
01602 
01603   if(uip_connr == 0) {
01604     /* All connections are used already, we drop packet and hope that
01605        the remote end will retransmit the packet at a time when we
01606        have more spare connections. */
01607     UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.tcp.syndrop);
01608     UIP_LOG("tcp: found no unused connections.");
01609     goto drop;
01610   }
01611   uip_conn = uip_connr;
01612   
01613   /* Fill in the necessary fields for the new connection. */
01614   uip_connr->rto = uip_connr->timer = UIP_RTO;
01615   uip_connr->sa = 0;
01616   uip_connr->sv = 4;
01617   uip_connr->nrtx = 0;
01618   uip_connr->lport = UIP_TCP_BUF->destport;
01619   uip_connr->rport = UIP_TCP_BUF->srcport;
01620   uip_ipaddr_copy(&uip_connr->ripaddr, &UIP_IP_BUF->srcipaddr);
01621   uip_connr->tcpstateflags = UIP_SYN_RCVD;
01622 
01623   uip_connr->snd_nxt[0] = iss[0];
01624   uip_connr->snd_nxt[1] = iss[1];
01625   uip_connr->snd_nxt[2] = iss[2];
01626   uip_connr->snd_nxt[3] = iss[3];
01627   uip_connr->len = 1;
01628 
01629   /* rcv_nxt should be the seqno from the incoming packet + 1. */
01630   uip_connr->rcv_nxt[3] = UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[3];
01631   uip_connr->rcv_nxt[2] = UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[2];
01632   uip_connr->rcv_nxt[1] = UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[1];
01633   uip_connr->rcv_nxt[0] = UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[0];
01634   uip_add_rcv_nxt(1);
01635 
01636   /* Parse the TCP MSS option, if present. */
01637   if((UIP_TCP_BUF->tcpoffset & 0xf0) > 0x50) {
01638     for(c = 0; c < ((UIP_TCP_BUF->tcpoffset >> 4) - 5) << 2 ;) {
01639       opt = uip_buf[UIP_TCPIP_HLEN + UIP_LLH_LEN + c];
01640       if(opt == TCP_OPT_END) {
01641         /* End of options. */
01642         break;
01643       } else if(opt == TCP_OPT_NOOP) {
01644         ++c;
01645         /* NOP option. */
01646       } else if(opt == TCP_OPT_MSS &&
01647                 uip_buf[UIP_TCPIP_HLEN + UIP_LLH_LEN + 1 + c] == TCP_OPT_MSS_LEN) {
01648         /* An MSS option with the right option length. */
01649         tmp16 = ((u16_t)uip_buf[UIP_TCPIP_HLEN + UIP_LLH_LEN + 2 + c] << 8) |
01650           (u16_t)uip_buf[UIP_IPTCPH_LEN + UIP_LLH_LEN + 3 + c];
01651         uip_connr->initialmss = uip_connr->mss =
01652           tmp16 > UIP_TCP_MSS? UIP_TCP_MSS: tmp16;
01653    
01654         /* And we are done processing options. */
01655         break;
01656       } else {
01657         /* All other options have a length field, so that we easily
01658            can skip past them. */
01659         if(uip_buf[UIP_TCPIP_HLEN + UIP_LLH_LEN + 1 + c] == 0) {
01660           /* If the length field is zero, the options are malformed
01661              and we don't process them further. */
01662           break;
01663         }
01664         c += uip_buf[UIP_TCPIP_HLEN + UIP_LLH_LEN + 1 + c];
01665       }
01666     }
01667   }
01668   
01669   /* Our response will be a SYNACK. */
01670 #if UIP_ACTIVE_OPEN
01671  tcp_send_synack:
01672   UIP_TCP_BUF->flags = TCP_ACK;
01673   
01674  tcp_send_syn:
01675   UIP_TCP_BUF->flags |= TCP_SYN;
01676 #else /* UIP_ACTIVE_OPEN */
01677  tcp_send_synack:
01678   UIP_TCP_BUF->flags = TCP_SYN | TCP_ACK;
01679 #endif /* UIP_ACTIVE_OPEN */
01680   
01681   /* We send out the TCP Maximum Segment Size option with our
01682      SYNACK. */
01683   UIP_TCP_BUF->optdata[0] = TCP_OPT_MSS;
01684   UIP_TCP_BUF->optdata[1] = TCP_OPT_MSS_LEN;
01685   UIP_TCP_BUF->optdata[2] = (UIP_TCP_MSS) / 256;
01686   UIP_TCP_BUF->optdata[3] = (UIP_TCP_MSS) & 255;
01687   uip_len = UIP_IPTCPH_LEN + TCP_OPT_MSS_LEN;
01688   UIP_TCP_BUF->tcpoffset = ((UIP_TCPH_LEN + TCP_OPT_MSS_LEN) / 4) << 4;
01689   goto tcp_send;
01690 
01691   /* This label will be jumped to if we found an active connection. */
01692  found:
01693   PRINTF("In found\n");
01694   uip_conn = uip_connr;
01695   uip_flags = 0;
01696   /* We do a very naive form of TCP reset processing; we just accept
01697      any RST and kill our connection. We should in fact check if the
01698      sequence number of this reset is wihtin our advertised window
01699      before we accept the reset. */
01700   if(UIP_TCP_BUF->flags & TCP_RST) {
01701     uip_connr->tcpstateflags = UIP_CLOSED;
01702     UIP_LOG("tcp: got reset, aborting connection.");
01703     uip_flags = UIP_ABORT;
01704     UIP_APPCALL();
01705     goto drop;
01706   }
01707   /* Calculate the length of the data, if the application has sent
01708      any data to us. */
01709   c = (UIP_TCP_BUF->tcpoffset >> 4) << 2;
01710   /* uip_len will contain the length of the actual TCP data. This is
01711      calculated by subtracing the length of the TCP header (in
01712      c) and the length of the IP header (20 bytes). */
01713   uip_len = uip_len - c - UIP_IPH_LEN;
01714 
01715   /* First, check if the sequence number of the incoming packet is
01716      what we're expecting next. If not, we send out an ACK with the
01717      correct numbers in, unless we are in the SYN_RCVD state and
01718      receive a SYN, in which case we should retransmit our SYNACK
01719      (which is done futher down). */
01720   if(!((((uip_connr->tcpstateflags & UIP_TS_MASK) == UIP_SYN_SENT) &&
01721         ((UIP_TCP_BUF->flags & TCP_CTL) == (TCP_SYN | TCP_ACK))) ||
01722        (((uip_connr->tcpstateflags & UIP_TS_MASK) == UIP_SYN_RCVD) &&
01723         ((UIP_TCP_BUF->flags & TCP_CTL) == TCP_SYN)))) {
01724     if((uip_len > 0 || ((UIP_TCP_BUF->flags & (TCP_SYN | TCP_FIN)) != 0)) &&
01725        (UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[0] != uip_connr->rcv_nxt[0] ||
01726         UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[1] != uip_connr->rcv_nxt[1] ||
01727         UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[2] != uip_connr->rcv_nxt[2] ||
01728         UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[3] != uip_connr->rcv_nxt[3])) {
01729 
01730       if(UIP_TCP_BUF->flags & TCP_SYN) {
01731         goto tcp_send_synack;
01732       }
01733       goto tcp_send_ack;
01734     }
01735   }
01736 
01737   /* Next, check if the incoming segment acknowledges any outstanding
01738      data. If so, we update the sequence number, reset the length of
01739      the outstanding data, calculate RTT estimations, and reset the
01740      retransmission timer. */
01741   if((UIP_TCP_BUF->flags & TCP_ACK) && uip_outstanding(uip_connr)) {
01742     uip_add32(uip_connr->snd_nxt, uip_connr->len);
01743 
01744     if(UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[0] == uip_acc32[0] &&
01745        UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[1] == uip_acc32[1] &&
01746        UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[2] == uip_acc32[2] &&
01747        UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[3] == uip_acc32[3]) {
01748       /* Update sequence number. */
01749       uip_connr->snd_nxt[0] = uip_acc32[0];
01750       uip_connr->snd_nxt[1] = uip_acc32[1];
01751       uip_connr->snd_nxt[2] = uip_acc32[2];
01752       uip_connr->snd_nxt[3] = uip_acc32[3];
01753    
01754       /* Do RTT estimation, unless we have done retransmissions. */
01755       if(uip_connr->nrtx == 0) {
01756         signed char m;
01757         m = uip_connr->rto - uip_connr->timer;
01758         /* This is taken directly from VJs original code in his paper */
01759         m = m - (uip_connr->sa >> 3);
01760         uip_connr->sa += m;
01761         if(m < 0) {
01762           m = -m;
01763         }
01764         m = m - (uip_connr->sv >> 2);
01765         uip_connr->sv += m;
01766         uip_connr->rto = (uip_connr->sa >> 3) + uip_connr->sv;
01767 
01768       }
01769       /* Set the acknowledged flag. */
01770       uip_flags = UIP_ACKDATA;
01771       /* Reset the retransmission timer. */
01772       uip_connr->timer = uip_connr->rto;
01773 
01774       /* Reset length of outstanding data. */
01775       uip_connr->len = 0;
01776     }
01777     
01778   }
01779 
01780   /* Do different things depending on in what state the connection is. */
01781   switch(uip_connr->tcpstateflags & UIP_TS_MASK) {
01782     /* CLOSED and LISTEN are not handled here. CLOSE_WAIT is not
01783        implemented, since we force the application to close when the
01784        peer sends a FIN (hence the application goes directly from
01785        ESTABLISHED to LAST_ACK). */
01786     case UIP_SYN_RCVD:
01787       /* In SYN_RCVD we have sent out a SYNACK in response to a SYN, and
01788          we are waiting for an ACK that acknowledges the data we sent
01789          out the last time. Therefore, we want to have the UIP_ACKDATA
01790          flag set. If so, we enter the ESTABLISHED state. */
01791       if(uip_flags & UIP_ACKDATA) {
01792         uip_connr->tcpstateflags = UIP_ESTABLISHED;
01793         uip_flags = UIP_CONNECTED;
01794         uip_connr->len = 0;
01795         if(uip_len > 0) {
01796           uip_flags |= UIP_NEWDATA;
01797           uip_add_rcv_nxt(uip_len);
01798         }
01799         uip_slen = 0;
01800         UIP_APPCALL();
01801         goto appsend;
01802       }
01803       /* We need to retransmit the SYNACK */
01804       if((UIP_TCP_BUF->flags & TCP_CTL) == TCP_SYN) {
01805         goto tcp_send_synack;
01806       }
01807       goto drop;
01808 #if UIP_ACTIVE_OPEN
01809     case UIP_SYN_SENT:
01810       /* In SYN_SENT, we wait for a SYNACK that is sent in response to
01811          our SYN. The rcv_nxt is set to sequence number in the SYNACK
01812          plus one, and we send an ACK. We move into the ESTABLISHED
01813          state. */
01814       if((uip_flags & UIP_ACKDATA) &&
01815          (UIP_TCP_BUF->flags & TCP_CTL) == (TCP_SYN | TCP_ACK)) {
01816 
01817         /* Parse the TCP MSS option, if present. */
01818         if((UIP_TCP_BUF->tcpoffset & 0xf0) > 0x50) {
01819           for(c = 0; c < ((UIP_TCP_BUF->tcpoffset >> 4) - 5) << 2 ;) {
01820             opt = uip_buf[UIP_IPTCPH_LEN + UIP_LLH_LEN + c];
01821             if(opt == TCP_OPT_END) {
01822               /* End of options. */
01823               break;
01824             } else if(opt == TCP_OPT_NOOP) {
01825               ++c;
01826               /* NOP option. */
01827             } else if(opt == TCP_OPT_MSS &&
01828                       uip_buf[UIP_TCPIP_HLEN + UIP_LLH_LEN + 1 + c] == TCP_OPT_MSS_LEN) {
01829               /* An MSS option with the right option length. */
01830               tmp16 = (uip_buf[UIP_TCPIP_HLEN + UIP_LLH_LEN + 2 + c] << 8) |
01831                 uip_buf[UIP_TCPIP_HLEN + UIP_LLH_LEN + 3 + c];
01832               uip_connr->initialmss =
01833                 uip_connr->mss = tmp16 > UIP_TCP_MSS? UIP_TCP_MSS: tmp16;
01834 
01835               /* And we are done processing options. */
01836               break;
01837             } else {
01838               /* All other options have a length field, so that we easily
01839                  can skip past them. */
01840               if(uip_buf[UIP_TCPIP_HLEN + UIP_LLH_LEN + 1 + c] == 0) {
01841                 /* If the length field is zero, the options are malformed
01842                    and we don't process them further. */
01843                 break;
01844               }
01845               c += uip_buf[UIP_TCPIP_HLEN + UIP_LLH_LEN + 1 + c];
01846             }
01847           }
01848         }
01849         uip_connr->tcpstateflags = UIP_ESTABLISHED;
01850         uip_connr->rcv_nxt[0] = UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[0];
01851         uip_connr->rcv_nxt[1] = UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[1];
01852         uip_connr->rcv_nxt[2] = UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[2];
01853         uip_connr->rcv_nxt[3] = UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[3];
01854         uip_add_rcv_nxt(1);
01855         uip_flags = UIP_CONNECTED | UIP_NEWDATA;
01856         uip_connr->len = 0;
01857         uip_len = 0;
01858         uip_slen = 0;
01859         UIP_APPCALL();
01860         goto appsend;
01861       }
01862       /* Inform the application that the connection failed */
01863       uip_flags = UIP_ABORT;
01864       UIP_APPCALL();
01865       /* The connection is closed after we send the RST */
01866       uip_conn->tcpstateflags = UIP_CLOSED;
01867       goto reset;
01868 #endif /* UIP_ACTIVE_OPEN */
01869     
01870     case UIP_ESTABLISHED:
01871       /* In the ESTABLISHED state, we call upon the application to feed
01872          data into the uip_buf. If the UIP_ACKDATA flag is set, the
01873          application should put new data into the buffer, otherwise we are
01874          retransmitting an old segment, and the application should put that
01875          data into the buffer.
01876 
01877          If the incoming packet is a FIN, we should close the connection on
01878          this side as well, and we send out a FIN and enter the LAST_ACK
01879          state. We require that there is no outstanding data; otherwise the
01880          sequence numbers will be screwed up. */
01881 
01882       if(UIP_TCP_BUF->flags & TCP_FIN && !(uip_connr->tcpstateflags & UIP_STOPPED)) {
01883         if(uip_outstanding(uip_connr)) {
01884           goto drop;
01885         }
01886         uip_add_rcv_nxt(1 + uip_len);
01887         uip_flags |= UIP_CLOSE;
01888         if(uip_len > 0) {
01889           uip_flags |= UIP_NEWDATA;
01890         }
01891         UIP_APPCALL();
01892         uip_connr->len = 1;
01893         uip_connr->tcpstateflags = UIP_LAST_ACK;
01894         uip_connr->nrtx = 0;
01895       tcp_send_finack:
01896         UIP_TCP_BUF->flags = TCP_FIN | TCP_ACK;
01897         goto tcp_send_nodata;
01898       }
01899 
01900       /* Check the URG flag. If this is set, the segment carries urgent
01901          data that we must pass to the application. */
01902       if((UIP_TCP_BUF->flags & TCP_URG) != 0) {
01903 #if UIP_URGDATA > 0
01904         uip_urglen = (UIP_TCP_BUF->urgp[0] << 8) | UIP_TCP_BUF->urgp[1];
01905         if(uip_urglen > uip_len) {
01906           /* There is more urgent data in the next segment to come. */
01907           uip_urglen = uip_len;
01908         }
01909         uip_add_rcv_nxt(uip_urglen);
01910         uip_len -= uip_urglen;
01911         uip_urgdata = uip_appdata;
01912         uip_appdata += uip_urglen;
01913       } else {
01914         uip_urglen = 0;
01915 #else /* UIP_URGDATA > 0 */
01916         uip_appdata = ((char *)uip_appdata) + ((UIP_TCP_BUF->urgp[0] << 8) | UIP_TCP_BUF->urgp[1]);
01917         uip_len -= (UIP_TCP_BUF->urgp[0] << 8) | UIP_TCP_BUF->urgp[1];
01918 #endif /* UIP_URGDATA > 0 */
01919       }
01920 
01921       /* If uip_len > 0 we have TCP data in the packet, and we flag this
01922          by setting the UIP_NEWDATA flag and update the sequence number
01923          we acknowledge. If the application has stopped the dataflow
01924          using uip_stop(), we must not accept any data packets from the
01925          remote host. */
01926       if(uip_len > 0 && !(uip_connr->tcpstateflags & UIP_STOPPED)) {
01927         uip_flags |= UIP_NEWDATA;
01928         uip_add_rcv_nxt(uip_len);
01929       }
01930 
01931       /* Check if the available buffer space advertised by the other end
01932          is smaller than the initial MSS for this connection. If so, we
01933          set the current MSS to the window size to ensure that the
01934          application does not send more data than the other end can
01935          handle.
01936 
01937          If the remote host advertises a zero window, we set the MSS to
01938          the initial MSS so that the application will send an entire MSS
01939          of data. This data will not be acknowledged by the receiver,
01940          and the application will retransmit it. This is called the
01941          "persistent timer" and uses the retransmission mechanim.
01942       */
01943       tmp16 = ((u16_t)UIP_TCP_BUF->wnd[0] << 8) + (u16_t)UIP_TCP_BUF->wnd[1];
01944       if(tmp16 > uip_connr->initialmss ||
01945          tmp16 == 0) {
01946         tmp16 = uip_connr->initialmss;
01947       }
01948       uip_connr->mss = tmp16;
01949 
01950       /* If this packet constitutes an ACK for outstanding data (flagged
01951          by the UIP_ACKDATA flag, we should call the application since it
01952          might want to send more data. If the incoming packet had data
01953          from the peer (as flagged by the UIP_NEWDATA flag), the
01954          application must also be notified.
01955 
01956          When the application is called, the global variable uip_len
01957          contains the length of the incoming data. The application can
01958          access the incoming data through the global pointer
01959          uip_appdata, which usually points UIP_IPTCPH_LEN + UIP_LLH_LEN
01960          bytes into the uip_buf array.
01961 
01962          If the application wishes to send any data, this data should be
01963          put into the uip_appdata and the length of the data should be
01964          put into uip_len. If the application don't have any data to
01965          send, uip_len must be set to 0. */
01966       if(uip_flags & (UIP_NEWDATA | UIP_ACKDATA)) {
01967         uip_slen = 0;
01968         UIP_APPCALL();
01969 
01970       appsend:
01971       
01972         if(uip_flags & UIP_ABORT) {
01973           uip_slen = 0;
01974           uip_connr->tcpstateflags = UIP_CLOSED;
01975           UIP_TCP_BUF->flags = TCP_RST | TCP_ACK;
01976           goto tcp_send_nodata;
01977         }
01978 
01979         if(uip_flags & UIP_CLOSE) {
01980           uip_slen = 0;
01981           uip_connr->len = 1;
01982           uip_connr->tcpstateflags = UIP_FIN_WAIT_1;
01983           uip_connr->nrtx = 0;
01984           UIP_TCP_BUF->flags = TCP_FIN | TCP_ACK;
01985           goto tcp_send_nodata;
01986         }
01987 
01988         /* If uip_slen > 0, the application has data to be sent. */
01989         if(uip_slen > 0) {
01990 
01991           /* If the connection has acknowledged data, the contents of
01992              the ->len variable should be discarded. */
01993           if((uip_flags & UIP_ACKDATA) != 0) {
01994             uip_connr->len = 0;
01995           }
01996 
01997           /* If the ->len variable is non-zero the connection has
01998              already data in transit and cannot send anymore right
01999              now. */
02000           if(uip_connr->len == 0) {
02001 
02002             /* The application cannot send more than what is allowed by
02003                the mss (the minumum of the MSS and the available
02004                window). */
02005             if(uip_slen > uip_connr->mss) {
02006               uip_slen = uip_connr->mss;
02007             }
02008 
02009             /* Remember how much data we send out now so that we know
02010                when everything has been acknowledged. */
02011             uip_connr->len = uip_slen;
02012           } else {
02013 
02014             /* If the application already had unacknowledged data, we
02015                make sure that the application does not send (i.e.,
02016                retransmit) out more than it previously sent out. */
02017             uip_slen = uip_connr->len;
02018           }
02019         }
02020         uip_connr->nrtx = 0;
02021       apprexmit:
02022         uip_appdata = uip_sappdata;
02023       
02024         /* If the application has data to be sent, or if the incoming
02025            packet had new data in it, we must send out a packet. */
02026         if(uip_slen > 0 && uip_connr->len > 0) {
02027           /* Add the length of the IP and TCP headers. */
02028           uip_len = uip_connr->len + UIP_TCPIP_HLEN;
02029           /* We always set the ACK flag in response packets. */
02030           UIP_TCP_BUF->flags = TCP_ACK | TCP_PSH;
02031           /* Send the packet. */
02032           goto tcp_send_noopts;
02033         }
02034         /* If there is no data to send, just send out a pure ACK if
02035            there is newdata. */
02036         if(uip_flags & UIP_NEWDATA) {
02037           uip_len = UIP_TCPIP_HLEN;
02038           UIP_TCP_BUF->flags = TCP_ACK;
02039           goto tcp_send_noopts;
02040         }
02041       }
02042       goto drop;
02043     case UIP_LAST_ACK:
02044       /* We can close this connection if the peer has acknowledged our
02045          FIN. This is indicated by the UIP_ACKDATA flag. */
02046       if(uip_flags & UIP_ACKDATA) {
02047         uip_connr->tcpstateflags = UIP_CLOSED;
02048         uip_flags = UIP_CLOSE;
02049         UIP_APPCALL();
02050       }
02051       break;
02052     
02053     case UIP_FIN_WAIT_1:
02054       /* The application has closed the connection, but the remote host
02055          hasn't closed its end yet. Thus we do nothing but wait for a
02056          FIN from the other side. */
02057       if(uip_len > 0) {
02058         uip_add_rcv_nxt(uip_len);
02059       }
02060       if(UIP_TCP_BUF->flags & TCP_FIN) {
02061         if(uip_flags & UIP_ACKDATA) {
02062           uip_connr->tcpstateflags = UIP_TIME_WAIT;
02063           uip_connr->timer = 0;
02064           uip_connr->len = 0;
02065         } else {
02066           uip_connr->tcpstateflags = UIP_CLOSING;
02067         }
02068         uip_add_rcv_nxt(1);
02069         uip_flags = UIP_CLOSE;
02070         UIP_APPCALL();
02071         goto tcp_send_ack;
02072       } else if(uip_flags & UIP_ACKDATA) {
02073         uip_connr->tcpstateflags = UIP_FIN_WAIT_2;
02074         uip_connr->len = 0;
02075         goto drop;
02076       }
02077       if(uip_len > 0) {
02078         goto tcp_send_ack;
02079       }
02080       goto drop;
02081       
02082     case UIP_FIN_WAIT_2:
02083       if(uip_len > 0) {
02084         uip_add_rcv_nxt(uip_len);
02085       }
02086       if(UIP_TCP_BUF->flags & TCP_FIN) {
02087         uip_connr->tcpstateflags = UIP_TIME_WAIT;
02088         uip_connr->timer = 0;
02089         uip_add_rcv_nxt(1);
02090         uip_flags = UIP_CLOSE;
02091         UIP_APPCALL();
02092         goto tcp_send_ack;
02093       }
02094       if(uip_len > 0) {
02095         goto tcp_send_ack;
02096       }
02097       goto drop;
02098 
02099     case UIP_TIME_WAIT:
02100       goto tcp_send_ack;
02101     
02102     case UIP_CLOSING:
02103       if(uip_flags & UIP_ACKDATA) {
02104         uip_connr->tcpstateflags = UIP_TIME_WAIT;
02105         uip_connr->timer = 0;
02106       }
02107   }
02108   goto drop;
02109   
02110   /* We jump here when we are ready to send the packet, and just want
02111      to set the appropriate TCP sequence numbers in the TCP header. */
02112  tcp_send_ack:
02113   UIP_TCP_BUF->flags = TCP_ACK;
02114 
02115  tcp_send_nodata:
02116   uip_len = UIP_IPTCPH_LEN;
02117 
02118  tcp_send_noopts:
02119   UIP_TCP_BUF->tcpoffset = (UIP_TCPH_LEN / 4) << 4;
02120 
02121   /* We're done with the input processing. We are now ready to send a
02122      reply. Our job is to fill in all the fields of the TCP and IP
02123      headers before calculating the checksum and finally send the
02124      packet. */
02125  tcp_send:
02126   PRINTF("In tcp_send\n");
02127    
02128   UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[0] = uip_connr->rcv_nxt[0];
02129   UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[1] = uip_connr->rcv_nxt[1];
02130   UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[2] = uip_connr->rcv_nxt[2];
02131   UIP_TCP_BUF->ackno[3] = uip_connr->rcv_nxt[3];
02132   
02133   UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[0] = uip_connr->snd_nxt[0];
02134   UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[1] = uip_connr->snd_nxt[1];
02135   UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[2] = uip_connr->snd_nxt[2];
02136   UIP_TCP_BUF->seqno[3] = uip_connr->snd_nxt[3];
02137 
02138   UIP_IP_BUF->proto = UIP_PROTO_TCP;
02139   
02140   UIP_TCP_BUF->srcport  = uip_connr->lport;
02141   UIP_TCP_BUF->destport = uip_connr->rport;
02142 
02143 
02144   uip_ipaddr_copy(&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr, &uip_connr->ripaddr);
02145   uip_ds6_select_src(&UIP_IP_BUF->srcipaddr,&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr);
02146   PRINTF("Sending TCP packet to");
02147   PRINT6ADDR(&UIP_IP_BUF->destipaddr);
02148   PRINTF("from");
02149   PRINT6ADDR(&UIP_IP_BUF->srcipaddr);
02150   PRINTF("\n");
02151       
02152   if(uip_connr->tcpstateflags & UIP_STOPPED) {
02153     /* If the connection has issued uip_stop(), we advertise a zero
02154        window so that the remote host will stop sending data. */
02155     UIP_TCP_BUF->wnd[0] = UIP_TCP_BUF->wnd[1] = 0;
02156   } else {
02157     UIP_TCP_BUF->wnd[0] = ((UIP_RECEIVE_WINDOW) >> 8);
02158     UIP_TCP_BUF->wnd[1] = ((UIP_RECEIVE_WINDOW) & 0xff);
02159   }
02160 
02161  tcp_send_noconn:
02162   UIP_IP_BUF->ttl = uip_ds6_if.cur_hop_limit;
02163   UIP_IP_BUF->len[0] = ((uip_len - UIP_IPH_LEN) >> 8);
02164   UIP_IP_BUF->len[1] = ((uip_len - UIP_IPH_LEN) & 0xff);
02165 
02166   UIP_TCP_BUF->urgp[0] = UIP_TCP_BUF->urgp[1] = 0;
02167   
02168   /* Calculate TCP checksum. */
02169   UIP_TCP_BUF->tcpchksum = 0;
02170   UIP_TCP_BUF->tcpchksum = ~(uip_tcpchksum());
02171   UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.tcp.sent);
02172 
02173 #endif /* UIP_TCP */
02174 #if UIP_UDP
02175  ip_send_nolen:
02176 #endif
02177   UIP_IP_BUF->vtc = 0x60;
02178   UIP_IP_BUF->tcflow = 0x00;
02179   UIP_IP_BUF->flow = 0x00;
02180  send:
02181   PRINTF("Sending packet with length %d (%d)\n", uip_len,
02182          (UIP_IP_BUF->len[0] << 8) | UIP_IP_BUF->len[1]);
02183   
02184   UIP_STAT(++uip_stat.ip.sent);
02185   /* Return and let the caller do the actual transmission. */
02186   uip_flags = 0;
02187   return;
02188 
02189  drop:
02190   uip_len = 0;
02191   uip_ext_len = 0;
02192   uip_ext_bitmap = 0;
02193   uip_flags = 0;
02194   return;
02195 }
02196 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
02197 u16_t
02198 uip_htons(u16_t val)
02199 {
02200   return UIP_HTONS(val);
02201 }
02202 
02203 u32_t
02204 uip_htonl(u32_t val)
02205 {
02206   return UIP_HTONL(val);
02207 }
02208 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
02209 void
02210 uip_send(const void *data, int len)
02211 {
02212   int copylen;
02213 #define MIN(a,b) ((a) < (b)? (a): (b))
02214   copylen = MIN(len, UIP_BUFSIZE - UIP_LLH_LEN - UIP_TCPIP_HLEN -
02215                 (int)((char *)uip_sappdata - (char *)&uip_buf[UIP_LLH_LEN + UIP_TCPIP_HLEN]));
02216   if(copylen > 0) {
02217     uip_slen = copylen;
02218     if(data != uip_sappdata) {
02219       memcpy(uip_sappdata, (data), uip_slen);
02220     }
02221   }
02222 }
02223 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
02224 /** @} */
